content: The Act titled "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for disclosure, limits on soft money of national political party committees, and miscellaneous provisions. It also mandates additional monthly and quarterly disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, increased electronic disclosure, and public access to broadcasting records. Title I of the "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for disclosure, penalties update, activities of membership organizations, and filing Senate reports with the Federal Election Commission. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 regarding reporting requirements for principal campaign committees. Monthly reports must be filed by the 20th day after the last day of the month, except for November and December. Quarterly reports are also required. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to include reporting requirements for principal campaign committees. Quarterly reports must be filed by the 15th day after the end of each calendar quarter, with the exception of the quarter ending December 31, which must be filed by January 31 of the following year. Additionally, a national committee of a political party is required to file the reports specified. The Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require monthly reports instead of quarterly reports. Additionally, the reporting timeframe is changed from calendar quarters to months. SEC. 102. REPORTING BY NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national and congressional political committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period. Political committees must separately itemize reporting for any person who contributes over $200 in a calendar year. Reports required to be filed under this subsection shall be filed for the same time periods required for political committees. SEC. 103 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require the Commission to make reports available on the Internet within 24 hours. SEC. 104 addresses public access to broadcasting records. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to require licensees to maintain and make public a record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. Licensees must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters, including acceptance/rejection, rates, air date/time, class of time, candidate's name and office sought, election or issue referenced. Licensees must maintain a record of requests to purchase broadcast time for political matters, including candidate information and contact details of the person purchasing the time. This information must be placed in a political file as soon as possible and retained for at least 2 years. SEC. 201. LIMIT ON SOFT MONEY OF NATIONAL POLITICAL PARTY COMMITTEES. Amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to impose limits on soft money contributions by national political party committees. SEC. 201 imposes limits on donations to political party committees, restricting individuals from donating more than $90,000 in a calendar year. In calendar years after 2001, amounts in subsections (a) and (b) will be increased based on the price index determined under section 315(c), with the base period being 2001. Each increased amount will be effective for that calendar year. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Expedited Review: Any Member of Congress, candidate, national committee of a political party, or any person affected by section 323 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 may bring an action in the US District Court for the District of Columbia for declaratory judgment and injunctive relief on the grounds of constitutionality. Appeal to Supreme Court: Any order of the US District Court for the District of Columbia regarding an action under subsection (a) is directly reviewable by the Supreme Court of the United States. The jurisdictional statement must be filed within 30 days of the order. The District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court must expedite the disposition of cases under subsection (a). Enforcement of section 323 of the Federal Election Campaign Act is stayed until final disposition by the Supreme Court. This section applies to actions filed within 30 days under subsection (a). Actions under subsection (a) must be filed within 30 days of this Act's effective date. SEC. 203: Increase in contribution limits. Increase in contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, including raising individual and political committee limits to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000 respectively, and multicandidate limits to $75,000. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits, including raising individual and political committee limits to $7,500 and $30,000 respectively. Additionally, a new limit of $15,000 is set for national committees of political parties in relation to any election for Federal office. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits, with limitations under subsection (a) remaining in effect for a 2-year period after the last general election. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for Senate candidate contribution limits for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees to $90,000. The amendments made by this section shall apply to calendar years beginning after December 31, 2001. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for Senate candidate contribution limits for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees to $90,000. The amendments made by subsection (c) shall apply to calendar years after December 31, 2002. SEC. 301. PROHIBITION OF SOLICITATION OF POLITICAL PARTY SOFT MONEY IN FEDERAL BUILDINGS. Section 607 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to define "contribution" in connection with elections for Federal office or political committees. Section 602(a)(4) is also amended to include prohibition of donations. The text chunk amends section 607 of title 18, United States Code, by defining "contribution" in connection with elections for Federal office or political committees. It also prohibits donations in section 602(a)(4) by inserting "(as defined in section 607(c))". SEC. 302 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to adjust penalty amounts for inflation after 2001. Each specified amount under subsection (a) or (d)(1)(A) will be increased based on the price index. SEC. 303 addresses activities of membership organizations and their affiliates. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to adjust penalty amounts for inflation after 2001. Section 316 of the Act is further amended to allow corporate members of trade associations to approve solicitations by multiple trade associations. Additionally, certain employees and individuals with professional responsibilities are redefined as executive and administrative personnel. Section 316 of the Act is further amended to allow corporate members of trade associations to approve solicitations by multiple trade associations. Additionally, certain employees and individuals with professional responsibilities are redefined as executive and administrative personnel. Individuals are classified as employees of the corporation for any other purpose. SEC. 304 requires Senate reports to be filed with the Federal Election Commission. Section 302 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to specify that all required filings must be submitted to the Commission. Conforming amendments in Title III clarify that filings should be made to both the Commission and the Secretary of State. In an amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, filings must now be submitted to the Commission instead of both the Commission and the Secretary of State.
